com.yantra.api.ycp.workflow

Interface manageTaskQueue

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    com.yantra.api.YCPApi, YIFApi

    public interface manageTaskQueue

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      org.w3c.dom.Document manageTaskQueue(YFSEnvironment env, org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
      The manageTaskQueue API can be used to create, modify, or delete Task Queue records.

    • Method Detail

      • manageTaskQueue

        org.w3c.dom.Document manageTaskQueue(YFSEnvironment env,
                                     org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
                              throws com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException,
                                     java.rmi.RemoteException

        The manageTaskQueue API can be used to create, modify, or delete Task Queue records.

        The default Operation for the API is Manage, which will act as Create if the specified task queue record does not exist, or as Modify if it does exist. Additionally, Delete can be passed to remove an existing task queue record.

        Every task is stamped with an Available Date (timestamp) at the time of creation and a task is considered ready for processing after the Available Date provided it is not on hold due to hold type (HOLD_FLAG in YFS_Task_Q is 'Y'). This date indicates the probable date after which the task request is likely to be processed successfully. There are various reasons why the processing of the request is deferred, such as:

        • Awaiting arrival of inventory
        • Honoring the delivery date on the order so that the order reaches the customer on the desired date

        It is possible to adjust this date using the manageTaskQueue API.

        Custom agent programs (extensions) can disable the repeated processing of a task request until the available date is reached by using the manageTaskQueue API. The custom agent program should calculate the next likely date based on logic that is appropriate for the business scenario, and then set the date on the task queue by calling this API.

        For example, assume that an order is awaiting scheduling. Although a schedule agent should pick the task queue request and start working on it, there would be significant overhead if the schedule agent executes the whole scheduling process at every run, only to determine that there is no inventory for a certain item. Unless the inventory is available, no matter how often the schedule agent runs, this order's task queue request will not be processed successfully. Instead of checking inventory availability at every run, the schedule agent could mark a next available date after the first attempt to schedule the order, based on the inventory availability information in the system. The scheduling agent can then ignore this task queue request in every subsequent run until the available date is reached. This ensures that the task request is processed only when it is most likely to be processed successfully.

        Related Documents
        Input XML Input DTD Output XML Output DTD Error XML Error DTD

        User Exits: None

        Events Raised: None

        Audits: None

        Pre-conditions: None

        Post-conditions:

          A record in YFS_TASK_Q will be inserted, updated, or deleted.

        Output Template Support: Yes

        Database Extensibility Support: No

        Parameters:
        env - Required. Environment handle returned by the createEnvironment API.
        inXML - Required. For more information, see the associated input xml files.

        Returns:
        An XML document that contains pipeline and drop status data. For details on the output, refer to the associated output files.

        Throws:
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException - Exception containing error codes in the standard error files.
        java.rmi.RemoteException - Java's default remote exception handler.
